posts.author: TyrTemplar
posts.content:
Reason why this has never happened is because different players have different styles, different PWs/needs/settings/ETC. I myself for example am known for PvP builds, love to solo PvM as well, but there is a very real difference when it comes to PvE which is a different environs. To put it another way: what does a great job depending on play style and understanding of class types--aka melee/STR vs. sneak/DEX vs. arcane/X--a power build for sure, as in level 40 power won't necessarily do you well when playing against the environment if want to solo PvE.

There is also a dfference when it comes to PvP 40 vs. actual playable power 1-40 PvM, though many of my own builds I do try to keep playability in mind, same "school" if you will as Mith (him and I loved our PvP, in particular "playable power" but sometimes I shoot for level 40 "excellence" and don't really care much about playability in turn, knowing it's a PvP/power build in turn (and clearly mark them as such---yes, builds should be marked playable range). That said, I have a "do not go zone" when it comes to XP burdens as that's not playable--no pain no gain yes, but XP burdens on top of that? Like I said, don't go there myself. Just don't, even if it means more power. On the other hand, if for PvP 40 ONLY I will note if for example that's what you want, then go some other race as if only interested in level 40 then an XP burden just don't matter. Others cringe at the thought, then, they are looking/building for 1-40 PvM/E with zero intention or desire to PvP, preferring playabilty over everything else and will not go in turn for power. And that is of course fine, as it's for PvM/E not PvP meaning, if it doesn't ever mature until level 40 and yet never going PvP so as to have no real life beyond 40, means never getting there so what is the point, right?

In addition, there is a very real difference in terms of magic settings as well--as in, are we playing/talking about low magic, mid-magic or high magic settings? It really does matter. For the most part, builds can be and should be tweaked by players who alone know best the worlds on which they are playing and what "gifts" if any they will be getting (we build default here, as can't possibly know and cannot be expected to know the rules on every single PW out there, but if a player tells us clearly what is going on then we as the ECB builders can and will help them adjust as such: our pleasure). But to pick a hall of fame, for what? Best Ab? Best AC? Best whatever? Oh, we love challenges here don't get me wrong. But generally speaking, when gut everything to achieve "best" whatever, chances are it's not very playable. Doesn't mean it's not worthy--I mean, did I mention that we LOVE, LOVE, LOVE challenges here? 'Never such a thing as a "Hall of Shame" in turn, all ideas/concepts/builds are welcome, and we will help and do help the junior builders get there. In the end, if you actually enjoy playing something whatever that may be--not just a paper character, in theory but actual build you enjoy playing, then we'll help you tweak it to make it better so that not only do you enjoy playing it more as in more efficient but, guess what? Congrats. Others will enjoy playing your build as well, meaning, it gets to go on and adventure in far flung PWs all over the place which you yourself may never have dreamed of when you first conceptualized and started playing your character. But if you don't enjoy playing it, opposite is also true in that probably the case that others won't either. Unless they're in a different setting, different magic, etc. So like all things, it depends...no such thing as a Hall of Shame in turn (unless you count some of the me big uber what have you with an INT 2 pretending to be uber whatever in responding to some of the builds, typically some PvP wanna be who as it turns out never actually PvP'd but can spot those types as soon as they post -- was rare, haven't seen it in eons, but heh that's what an INT 2 will do, yes? '_

Build ON! ~ Tyr

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hey, Tyr.

I can't speak for others about this, but for me, when I envision a Hall of Fame in building, I don't envision this "Guiness Book of Records" thing that you talked about. For me, it's about building finesse and just raw power of the builds. Now, if we use a "default setting" when building, then why not use the same setting for comparing builds and voting? What you say is true, you can't really avoid biases such as playstyle, personal preference and stuff, but do we really have to? You are more inclined for melee PvP builds, so you'll naturally tend to pick some of such builds as your favourites. I'm more of a self-buffer type of player, with a bit of an attraction (but not a predilection) for casting, so my favourite builds will probably reflect that. But even if you aren't a fan of a certain type of build, you can and should recognize the finesse it took for certain builds to be crafted. I'll name some of my faves here, which include some of my own builds.

Melee types:

- The Charnel Lord by Grizz
- Dwarven Wall of Wonders by StryderBlade
- The Citadel by Grizz
- Tear of the Dragon by Kail Pendragon and Conlaoch
- The HOOD by me
- Ugly Mug Hero by me

Caster Types:

- Exhalted Sorceress (forgot who made it)
- Order of Jormungandr by Kail Pendragon
- Champion of the Wilderness by me
- Demolition Man by me
- Speedy Caster by Whizard
- The Dracolich of Autumn Twilight by Grizz

Self-buffer types:

- The Magical Master by me
- Blood & Faith by Mith
- The Hierophant by Mith
- The Shadow Priest by me

and some others I forgot the name to. Bard PM RDD (16/14/10, 14/16/10 or 20/10/10), Bard 26 Fighter 4 RDD 10, etc..

Sneaker types (my least favourites):

Tiny Reaper by Grimnir
The Bane Crusher by me (a bit unplayable early on but can be tweaked if necessary)
Death says Yip (beautiful build, forgot who posted it and don't have time to look it up)

There are also other styles of builds and one specifically of my own that I've never published. It's sort of my take on Artemis Entreri from Bob Salvatore's books. I adapted it from my ED-SCV halfling into a drow fencer with a higher dex score and it was pretty cool. It was a Fighter 14 WM 7 Rogue 19 dex build, which can be played both as a sneaker or a defensive meleer. I can post both versions here, but not now cuz I am running out of time.

Anyway, it all boils down to personal preference, which is why some of my builds are in there too. I'm not saying that they're at the same level as the other builds, nor am I saying they aren't, but when you talk about favorites, then you can't be neutral, and out of all my builds, which is mostly what I play, these are my favourite ones. When I see a build from someone else such as the ones I have mentioned above, that I wouldn't tweak one bit to fit my playstyle, then I play that one too. Gotta go!

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
I have finished The Aielund Saga with The Shadow Priest, and you know that part where the golem army comes rushing in and you're fleeing back to Fort Highmarch in act III? I managed to stand alone with it (had to get rid of the henchmen cuz they kept dying on me) in the middle of the bridge where there's a patrol of Rangers. I was able to single-handedly defeat the entire Golem army with but a few scratches and bruises left on me .

As for Grizz's build, I'd personally go Ranger 9 Monk 9 WM 22 for +1 AB and +1 feat, I'd lose 1 AC and a couple of skill dumps, but it's more than worth it .

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Let me add to these fine builds some of my own favorites as well..


The Knight Commander by TyrTemplar, which is the most balanced (Great smiter/Divine warrior) of its kind with very close second the Guardian of Light by Mick Dagger.

The build has it all, Great Smite V, awesome saves, solid AB unbuffed, good damage, AC boosted by a generous ammount from Divine Shield, Undispellable Paladin buffs and wards, immunities and a nice synergy with Divine Wrath and Lay on Hands due to high charisma.

http://home.comcast.net/~worldofgreyhaw ... 45425.html


The Ghost Elf by Djinni Dream, a (Fighter/WM/SD) which is simply put the best of its kind. Incredible undispellable defenses along with WM augmented criticals, EWS and HiPS to get the job done.

http://z6.invisionfree.com/BrunderenCit ... topic=2189

posts.author: Templar
posts.content: Is it possible to get this pinned/stickied. Seems like something many would probably like to see consistently.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Actually, I had been thinking about creating a subforum some time ago (much like the one Kail and I discussed and implemented for the Bioware Legacy builds) now that the WoG Comcast server has been pulled down. 

It would require similar reformatting via Kamiryn's CBC to get them all loaded here but the direct access is worth the effort IMO.  Once I've finished uploading the new filter/search spreadsheet to the Neverwinter Vault, I'll begin to port them over... just the builds themselves, not the peripheral discussions.  Problem is: May begins my busy season which lasts into Oct., so during that period my access to the Web and ECB is sporadic and unpredictable.  But in the meantime, if you folks will make recommendations, at least when my "window" reopens in earnest in the Fall 2016, I'll have some candidate builds to start working on.

So, towards that effort ECB faithful... Just furnish a Title, Author and Class Combo Split and I should be able to locate each build within the legacy archive I am using on my local machine for conversion.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Arse that I am, while loving the idea (I suspect many of us are inveterate list makers - collective top 50 songs anyone?) and recognising the qualifiers given previously in this thread, I do find I have some questions: i) Do you have to have played the build, regardless of format?; ii) Can you include builds from the Build Request/Unfinished Builds forum that never hit the Epic Builds section (which would make Hip's life harder, but if he's buggering off for 6 months he deserves it - soz Hip)?; iii) Are we looking at 'optimized' power builds, or our favourites to play - which can be wildly different?; iv) Can newbie schmucks like me join in, despite never having seen/played/experienced many of the different builds or types of build on offer?; v) Can choices be questioned/disregarded?; vi) Are there restrictions on numbers/type of builds to be included?...I could babble on further, but won't. You get the picture.

I know I'm being anal here, but from past experience I've found it considerably better to get this crap out of the way early on.

Sorry

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
In my perspective on the history of this game, "Hall of Fame" builds are simply those that have proved the test of time, implemented first-hand by many players on diverse environments.  Domination on a few servers or within a small sample of CC modules/campaigns does not justify elevating any build further than just "appearing awesome".  And there are LOADS of those here!

To expand further, from 2002 to approximately 2010 when the legacy ECB Guild was shut down along with the associated Bioware forums which housed that guild, the number of players were astounding for most of that 8 year period.  The attendance of PWs was never higher (actually, they were all packed 24-7) and neither was the interest in new innovations.   Would you believe that a popular server like WoG would be so jambed you wouldn't be able to join until someone left?  Believe it. That was the norm in those days.  So much latency due to overcrowded servers. A different world.  The closing of the original forums/guilds didn't kill NWN but it diluted the subscribership severely.  Judging from my own experience of losing gaming pals, I'd estimate only 3 out of 10 regular gamers were left still playing a mere year after the loss of Bioware support. I was one of those "traitors" and have returned to some extent since then but with nowhere near the commitment to play.  Most divorces were final, though.

Today is a pale remnant of that era.  Comparatively, it's become impossible for such an all-encompassing fervor of that magnitude to reappear.  Just too many innovative graphic engines in on-line gaming and too much competition for attendance.  So what we are left with here is a combinations of a few ardent veterans along with newer players (complements of the digital market) in a relatively small NWN community that still hold a respectful level of enjoyment in the game, an appreciation that has extended its popularity as far as it has.

Therefore, (after enduring the tedious deliberation of backstory) it would only be builds that we no longer have direct access to that fall into that category, the thoroughly-proved concepts with well-established success histories.  As optimized as any build appears "on paper", until that concept has been severely tested in diverse situations and environments, its stature can only be approximated and its success anticipated.

Let's not muddle this good idea up with some hair-brained, cosmetic Vote system.  It's a waste of time and, TBH, totally impractical given the nature of the community's current size.   Hall of Fame in any frame of reference is based on volume of participation and duration of content.  There's no value in trying to force the term into another context like "ultimate optimization" of a concept.

Those Hall of Fame candidates should be obvious to all of us who have seen them perform universally and only those need be considered for conversion here for easy access (and, ideally to induce some further discussion in regards to new environments they may have found their way into since their zenith).

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hip, please don't get me wrong here - by and large I was playing devil's advocate, and not out of any sense of malice, merely that I've had to contend with similar issues in other arenas. So I have no problem sticking my head over the trench to cop for the flak if it makes things easier, and I absolutely agree with you regarding the 'vote' concept.

I do feel sad about the dwindling of the light, as one who has but recently discovered the options Neverwinter has to offer. As with many things, glitter trumps substance far too often. I appreciate the backstory, and am only sorry that I came upon the game so late in the day. Maybe one day...

That being said, I'd still like to throw my two-penneth-worth behind a couple of builds that are always a delight to play (feel free to ignore me): Order of the Wyrm - Empyre65 - Monk 25/Sorcerer 1/RDD 14; and Halfling Champion - Mick Dagger - Rogue 20/Fighter 6/CoT 14.

As Tyr might say...Build ON

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Hip, speaks some truths here...

The Golden Era of NwN 1 followed a sudden cut off of the Original forums and then 2/10 players remained, maybe less than that. After that the NwN Vault closed and that was the final wound. So many pages of discussions about the modules and the PW's were gone. Now only 2/100 players remain, maybe less than that. The loss of the Legacy ECB is just the icing on the cake. Maybe it is for the best, people will move on to something else instead or maybe a small (and smart) company like Beamdog did in the case of Baldur's Gate will come and revive this game from its ashes. I hope for the later.

On to the "Hall of Fame" builds, every one has its favorites, depending on its style and the server/modules that he/she plays. But to the trained eye, a really good build is always a really good build even if it isn't on that list. It doesn't take much for example to understand that Tyr's Dragon Slayer (Bard 8/ RDD 10/ COT 22)  with it's hefty (46+2) AB, its brutal 45 (51) DC Devastating Critical and excellent saves across the board (and over 500 HP's as well) is a hot thing and a candidate for that list as well, or that Mick's Epic Scholar  is the best (hands-down) April's Fool build ever to appear on these boards ;)

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Just to clarify my opinion since after reading it closer have become dubious as to how it might be interpreted and received...

I have no bias one way or the other whether this thread attempts to compile a "Greatest Hits" kind of list for readers to discuss from builds already posted here.  Any deliberation that incites interest in NWN is always most welcome and advantageous to our "cause".

But the potential I saw was in using this opportunity to nominate builds from the Legacy archive since those are not as easily discussed as they might be if posted within our new venue when converted as complete with full stats.  It's a list like that which would interest me most because I would enjoy reading how those builds have fared among some of the newer customizations being used, especially in environments that have implemented the newest version of the CEP, the Community Patch and innovative NPC AIs.  Besides, it would be great to compare them side-by-side with our members' contributions.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Just wondering if this build could be put in the Bioware legacy build section?

Came across it whilst looking at the 2008 builds. I thought it was great

The Charnel Lord: Fighter 12 / Bard 4 / Pale Master 24 by grizzled_dwarflord
http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/buil ... html#page1

Here's a fun quote from grizzled_dwarflord's post:

One foot in life...and one in the grave, and to bathe in the blood of his enemies his only constant..... 

Time once again for the guilty pleasure build. While not original in any way, he may be the best in his class. Forsooth, who here hasn�t wished to have a character with 40 AC in just regular Armor, swinging a Great Axe that delivers Devastating Crits with 4 attacks per round, every Epic Spell you could dream of and more, Immunities to criticals, Stuns and Paralysis, and the ability to summon liches, lich lords, and Epic Mummy Lords wielding +5 Katanas of Nastiness, while still retaining skills like Tumble, UMD, Taunt, Improved Knockdowns and the notorious Improved Disarm to give one that extra edge to situational AB? Surely a few of you still toss and turn at nights about such power�.

Whether his strength is granted from the divine above, or the infernal below, none know for certain, or even if it may actually come from someplace in between-- the graveyards, catacombs and charnel houses of this world where the restless dead still linger�and wait.

[...]

Master of Desolation
* Dwarven Beard
* A Keen Luster in his Eyes (Darkvision)
* Animate Dead: Tyrantfog Zombie, Skeletal Warrior & Chieftain
* Palemaster Death Touch: DC: 24
* Undead Summons (see below)
* Epic Mage Armor (24hours): +20 AC (allows the PC to drop AC items in favor of other items in +5 or less magic worlds)
* Epic Warding (24 Rounds): 50/+20 Damage Reduction (1200 point absorbtion)
* Devastating Critical: DC: 40 (max 46)
* Greater Ruin Blast: 35d6 Positive Energy nuke strike (the final blow, blasts through SR)
* Improved Disarm: Grants +situational AB against small or tiny weapons
* UMD: Can use scrolls, wands rods, outlawed magic items, etc�
* Healthy Taunt score: Helps to lower enemy�s AC to land some good crits and more situational +AB

Servants of the Charnel House
PM Level 4-5: Ghoul
PM Level 6: Shadow
PM Level 7: Ghast
PM Level 8: Wight
PM Level 9: Wraith
PM Level 9: Mummy Warrior 
PM Level 10: Spectre 
PM Level 12: Vampire Rogue 
PM Level 14: Greater Bodak 
PM Level 16: Ghoul King 
PM Level 18: Vampire Mage 
PM Level 20: Skeletal Blackguard 
PM Level 22: Lich & the Epic Mummy Lord (woo-hoo!)
PM Level 24: The Fell & Dreaded Lich Lord

Weaknesses
None
Edit:
Thanks Kalistez for your reply. Full build is here:
SpoilerOne foot in life...and one in the grave, and to bathe in the blood of his enemies his only constant.....






Level Guide 2 Bard1 4 Fighter3, Str19 6 Fighter5, Blindfighting 8 Fighter6, Knockdown, Str20 10 Fighter8, Improved Crit: Halberd 12 Fighter10, Disarm, Improved Disarm, Str21 14 Bard3 16 Palemaster2, Str22 18 Palemaster4, Toughness 20 Palemaster6, Str23 22 Palemaster8 24 Palemaster10, Great Str I, Str25 26 Palemaster12 28 Palemaster14, Str26 30 Fighter12, EWF: Halberd, EWS: Halberd) 33 Palemaster18, Epic Mage Armor 35 Palemaster20 37 Palemaster22, Epic Spell: Mummy Dust 39 Palemaster24, Epic Prowess
Combat Vitals: 40 (mundane plate): 40/35/30/25 (19-20/x3+2d6 --1d10+21(piercing and slashing): 470: Acid, 10/-: Sneak Attack, Criticals, Paralysis, Stun, Holds: Improved KD, Improved Disarm, Death Touch: 40 (46 max)

Skills:


Master of Desolation * A Keen Luster in his Eyes (Darkvision) * Palemaster Death Touch: DC: 24) * Epic Warding (24 Rounds): 50/+20 Damage Reduction (1200 point absorbtion) * Greater Ruin Blast: 35d6 Positive Energy nuke strike (the final blow, blasts through SR) * UMD: Can use scrolls, wands rods, outlawed magic items, etc�







Weaknesses



There's really no strategy here. This is a straight-up mauler. High AC and immunities allow him to outlast his opponents, and his heavy hitting Halberd insure that he takes his opponents out. Dev Crit will allow him to wade easily through the mobs, and his beard will insure you look good doing it. Not that he really needs them, but the built-in Undead Army, Epic Warding, Epic Mage Armor and Greater Ruin allow him to take on even the toughest opponents a module has to offer. UMD will allow him to self-buff via scrolls or wands if needed. Also, the Charnel Lord enjoys the luxury of several activated combat feats (Power Attack, Improved Disarm, Improved Knockdown). One could make a true AC monster by dropping either the IKD line or the Disarm and acquiring Expertise/Improved Expertise. With this in hand, one can gain a 70 AC without even using items (40 base+20EMA+10Improved Expertise). Cheers!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I thought it would be worthwhile if anyone play tests a classic build that isn't listed here, to put up a post about it in the hall of fame builds thread :)

So I'll start the ball rolling with a very classic build from 2004, 'The Enforcer' by Mithdradates

I recently game tested a very mildly modified version of this build to level 40, so I thought I would post a few comments on my experience using it, which was a pure delight.




World of Greyhawk, Adventurer's Guild. Level 40, +4 greatsword, capped strength (+12) from items, equipped with a chainmail of speed, buffed with shadow shield, premonition, mind blank, bless, aid and keen weapon.

Spoiler The original build:  Note I have edited the AB values from the original post as his original calculations were off as mentioned by Thaxll'ssillyia in the thread, just for clarity

-Evasion. Okay, the character has low saves, but that's what scarabs of protection are for. -Devastating critical.

Enforcer Level 1 Human, CG, Rogue














































Final Attributes DEX 13 WIS 10 CHA 8



AB and Damage (No buffs, regular greatsword) Devastating Critical DC 42 (+12 STR, true strike, +5 keen greatsword) Devastating Critical DC 48




Spoiler Modified version of the build - first rogue level at level 21 for +1 AB, dropped epic weapon specialisation Fighter(10), Rogue(2), Weapon Master(28), Human STR: 17 (34) CON: 14 INT: 14 01: Fighter(1): Blind Fight, Dodge, Weapon Focus: Greatsword 03: Fighter(3): Mobility 05: Fighter(5) 07: Fighter(7) 09: Weapon Master(1): Improved Critical: Greatsword, Weapon of Choice: Greatsword 11: Weapon Master(3) 13: Weapon Master(5) 15: Weapon Master(7): Power Attack 17: Fighter(10): Cleave 19: Weapon Master(9) 21: Weapon Master(11): Great Strength I, (STR=23) 23: Rogue(1) 25: Weapon Master(14) 27: Weapon Master(16): Great Strength III, Devastating Critical: Greatsword, (STR=26) 29: Weapon Master(18) 31: Weapon Master(20) 33: Weapon Master(22): Great Strength V, Epic Prowess, (STR=30) 35: Weapon Master(24) 37: Rogue(2): {Evasion} 39: Weapon Master(27): Great Strength VII, (STR=33) Skillpoints: 227 Saving Throw bonuses: Spells: +1 AB (max, naked): 53 (melee), 32 (ranged) Spell Casting:  01: Discipline(4), Heal(4), Intimidate(2), Save(8),  03: Discipline(1), Heal(1), Intimidate(1), Save(12),  05: Discipline(1), Heal(1), Intimidate(1), Save(16),  07: Discipline(1), Heal(1), Save(22),  09: Discipline(1), Heal(1), Listen(12), Save(16),  11: Discipline(1), Heal(1), Listen(1), Save(20),  13: Discipline(1), Heal(1), Listen(1), Save(24),  15: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Save(30),  17: Discipline(1), Save(38),  19: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Save(42),  21: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Save(48),  23: Listen(1), Open Lock(1), Search(10), Tumble(25), UMD(25),  25: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Save(5),  27: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Save(11),  29: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Save(17),  31: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Save(23),  33: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Save(29),  35: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Save(35),  37: Disable Trap(1), Listen(1), Search(9), Set Trap(14), Tumble(15), UMD(9),  39: Discipline(1), Listen(1), Spellcraft(1), Save(1), 
Anyway its a lovely build. 

Great AB (53 AB base), great damage with two handed and sky high strength, devastating critical, 500 odd hp, sneak attack, +8AC from tumble, evasion and UMD to be able to self buff with any spell in the game, particularly improved invisibility and mind blank.

In the screenshot my AB progression is 65/60/55/50, so my last attack hits and crits regularly. 

With the increased critical hit modifier to x3 and overwhelming critical, 30-40% of hits tend to critical hit damage for up to 130 damage which is just delightful.

Not to mention devastating critical, which is very valuable for those annoying high hp minions which get in the way of you reaching bosses.

Devastating critical generally will rarely be activated against bosses (they have to usually roll a 1 or something like that), but when it does it feels nice.

The major downside of the build is the terrible saves especially the will save, dispellability of buffs,  and lowish AC.

The saves can be worked around with UMD -> spells or items which grant immunities, for example clarity potions, scrolls of lesser mind blank/mind blank, fear immunity items, items which grant freedom, items which grant death immunity.

Dispellability I found best managed with using items with properties I need as these properties won't be dispelled. 

Another solution was a scroll of greater sanctuary or invisibility potion, walking up to an enemy mage and improved knockdown/dev critting them with your ridiculous AB, then using greater sanctuary (or invisibility even if you are allowed by the enemy) to escape also works well.

Low AC was a tricky problem which I managed with trying to engage 1v1 as much as possible and abuse the sky high AB with  improved knockdown. 

Mobs were a big problem. One could go sword and shield and use expertise but this is best in a party where a teammate can do the damage, as one will lose all that AB and damage output. Other buffs like improved invisibility etc for 50% concealment were very helpful.

Do I think Mithdradates's original version was better? Maybe. The AB is simply really good already, and dropping 1AB for epic weapon specialisation is probably worth it. 

Another option might be to take a fighter 12 / WM 25 / Rogue 3 split to include uncanny dodge and 2d6 sneak attack at the cost of the epic toughness feat. 

I'd love to make it a halfling for extra cheese by being able to wield a scimitar in two hands without losing any AB, adding 1AC and to +1 all saves, and having the maximal critical hit range in the game with keen weapon :) but then there are size penalties with knockdown to consider...

Anyway this is a fantastic build. 15 years on and still a splendid build

10/10 from me.

Edit: to be placed in the Hall of Fame Build thread when the moderators are able to do so

posts.author: unifiedworld
posts.content:
Maybe I just haven't seen it but it would be really nice to have a list of what are considered the best builds out there. I think the best way to categorize it would be by classes. The best pure fighters, the best fighter/wizards, the best bard/RDD/clerics, etc. Then, when people want to play a particular class or class combo, they could look at builds that are recognized as excellent. Expert builders (say, 10 or 20 of them, depending on how many are available) could give each build on the list a score (rank) and the average score could be published for each build. If it were a score from 1 to 10, for example, readers would get an idea about how good each build is based on the scores given by the experts.

I face a dilemma whenever I want to play a particular class. For example, for my next character, I want to play a druid or perhaps a ranger. It would be nice to be able to look at a Hall of Fame list to see which druid builds are considered to be the best out there. Currently, I use this link http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/builds/index.html and this tapatalk group's search feature, but it's really hard to find builds, and on top of that, it's really hard to know which builds are considered to be excellent.

If, say, 10 to 20 expert builders/players picked 1-3 of their favorite builds for each class combo, then all the builds were compiled and everyone gave each build a score from 1-10, you would end up with a list of builds categorized by class, each with a rating based on how expert builders evaluated them. Perhaps the best pure fighter build would end up with a rating of 2 because almost no one thought it would be any good! It would be interesting to see if any builds managed to get an average score of 10 - a perfect rating from all the evaluating builders. There may be some class combos that make no sense so no builds are selected or featured for that particular combination.

I myself don't feel confident or knowledgeable enough to participate as an expert, but I would certainly love to have such a list as a resource.

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
unifiedworld wrote:
May 30, 2021
Maybe I just haven't seen it but it would be really nice to have a list of what are considered the best builds out there. I think the best way to categorize it would be by classes. The best pure fighters, the best fighter/wizards, the best bard/RDD/clerics, etc. Then, when people want to play a particular class or class combo, they could look at builds that are recognized as excellent. Expert builders (say, 10 or 20 of them, depending on how many are available) could give each build on the list a score (rank) and the average score could be published for each build. If it were a score from 1 to 10, for example, readers would get an idea about how good each build is based on the scores given by the experts.

I face a dilemma whenever I want to play a particular class. For example, for my next character, I want to play a druid or perhaps a ranger. It would be nice to be able to look at a Hall of Fame list to see which druid builds are considered to be the best out there. Currently, I use this link http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/builds/index.html and this tapatalk group's search feature, but it's really hard to find builds, and on top of that, it's really hard to know which builds are considered to be excellent.

If, say, 10 to 20 expert builders/players picked 1-3 of their favorite builds for each class combo, then all the builds were compiled and everyone gave each build a score from 1-10, you would end up with a list of builds categorized by class, each with a rating based on how expert builders evaluated them. Perhaps the best pure fighter build would end up with a rating of 2 because almost no one thought it would be any good! It would be interesting to see if any builds managed to get an average score of 10 - a perfect rating from all the evaluating builders. There may be some class combos that make no sense so no builds are selected or featured for that particular combination.

I myself don't feel confident or knowledgeable enough to participate as an expert, but I would certainly love to have such a list as a resource.
Hey man!

I love the idea, and perhaps one day that will come to life, but as of now, you could start becoming more knowledgeable to perhaps represent the next generation of expert builders in this project. To that end, you could read many of the great guides we have in the Game Guides section.

I personally would categorize the builds by their functions, but there are always issues because many builds could fit multiple categories. I.E.: We could have, for example, an ARCANE SPELLSWORDS category, and another one called DIVINE SPELLSWORDS, but then there's my Magical Master, which fits both descriptions. We could have another category such as DEX-BASED EPIC-DODGERS, but then my Shadow Priest and Priest with a Secret Life would fit both that and Divine Spellswords as well. It's not doable by class, or class combo, because there are just too many builds and possible combinations. Perhaps if builds fit multiple categories, then they could be listed in both, provided they're good enough. Here's a rough list of the categories I would start with:

1- Pure Arcane Casters (not pure as in 40 levels of the same class, but as in casting is what they use to kill things):
2- Pure Divine Casters:
3- Dragon Shapers:
4- STR-based Arcane Spellswords:
5- STR-based Divine Spellswords:
6- DEX-based Arcane Spellswords:
7- DEX-based Divine Spellswords:
8- DEX-based Divine Spellbows:
9- WIS-based Divine Spellbows:
10- DEX-based Arcane Spellbows:
11- Dual-caster Spellswords:
12- Dual-caster Spellbows:
13- STR-based Juggernauts:
14- DEX-based Epic-Dodgers:
15- DR Tanks:
16- STR-based melee Bards
17- DEX-based melee Bards
18- General Shifters:
19- Shifters focused on a specific shape:
20- CHA-based Smiters.

etc.., etc.. etc..

There are just too many categories!!! It would be A LOT of work!

There's also the issue that, despite how good a build may be, knowing how to play it is paramount to extract the most value from it. I still remember talking to conlaoch, WAY BACK, when he told me in game that he had tried multiple Cleric builds, but was not able to get the juice from them that they could provide. I spent hours discussing strategies with him, explaining how he should manage his spellbook on a level-by-level basis, and then compiled that information and reformatted it to write my Cleric guide. He was basically memorizing lots of different buffs (including some that are sub-optimal at best), instead of multiple copies of the most important ones, like Divine Power, Divine favor, etc..., so he was constantly running out before the next rest.

This would have to be a long-term project that would need people to work on it for months on end to first come up with a good category system, and then look at ALL existing builds and define where they fit and what score they'd have in that category. I fear it may be biting off mother than we can chew to try to do this.

Cheers!

posts.author: unifiedworld
posts.content:
Maybe the categorization could happen last or just not be done at all.

Builders could just pick their favorite builds, or the ones they consider the best. Perhaps at least 10 but no more than 30, or something like that? Then, once everyone has picked their favorite builds, they could be compiled into a single list and each builder would go through the list, giving each build a score from 1 to 10, maybe allowing for up to one-two decimal points, for example 9.5 or 9.53, etc. The average rating of all the builders could be the final rating for that individual build. If we wanted to be really fancy, we could implement some way for people to share their comments or evaluations of individual builds with others during the rating process.

I guess there should also be some qualification of what each rating would represent. For example, what does it take for a build to get a 10? A 9? An 8? etc.

Also, there should be an option to not rate a particular build if one is not familiar enough with the playstyle/classes involved. In that case, the final rating will merely be an average rating of all the people who did rate the build. We don't really want people guessing whether a build is good or not. They should have enough experience and knowledge to feel confident enough to rate the build in question.

Perhaps, there could be a minimum rating needed for a build to make the final cut. For example, maybe an average rating of 7 or higher might be considered necessary for a build to be included.

Once all the qualifying builds are identified, they could be categorized however is deemed most appropriate, or even presented without categories, since the classes speak for themselves for the most part.

Ratings will always be subjective to some degree but that's the nature of these types of lists. Maybe there could be separate lists for PvM and PvP, or at least separate lists for 1-40 playable builds vs. level 40 builds. It might seem like a lot of work but we could just do one list at a time instead of trying to do them all at once. For example, first compile the best 1-40 PvM builds and then once that project is complete, compile the best PvP builds. Only people knowledgeable or confident enough need participate, so there would be no pressure on anyone. However, only the people who do participate would have their opinion counted in the final product.

Finally, there could be a process put in place for how to add new builds to the list, as surely there will be more builds that people will want to include once the final list is published.

Edit: All of that would be a lot of work but what about just an easily searchable list similar to: http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/builds/index.html but including all the builds on this site? That would make life easier when trying to find builds that have been done before. Maybe I'm just not very good at searching within this site.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
The main problem with a "best builds" catagory would be that much of this is dependent on the environment where it is going to be used in.

So in order to produce such a listings, one would first have to define the environment.  This would be, imho, the first big step.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
It's great to see such enthusiasm for the game and our builds @unifiedworld , and I take no joy in pouring cold water over your suggestion. But I'm going to.

Firstly, in the ten years this Guild has been running, there are only some 361 builds combined in our completed builds forums (Level 40, 30, 20 and Free). This is not down to incompetence or laziness by our builders. Rather, it is the opposite: diligence in researching what has gone before to avoid duplication (though there may be some overlap from when the Legacy Archive was not available); and also not being prepared to post either untested or sub-standard builds with their names on them. They all serve their own purposes and may be relied upon to perform as advertised, or they would not be there. And if one or two slip through the net, the moderators will move them to the Unfinalized Builds forum.

Secondly, in what Library will you find a section titled "Our Best Books"? Or a restaurant having "Our Best Dish" on its menu? It is up to the customer to choose. Certainly, one can say "this is the most borrowed book" or "our most popular dish", but that is far from the same thing. And, indeed, individual librarians and chefs will have their own preferences, but that is what they are. If you want a recommendation, ask, nothing wrong with that at all. Otherwise, try different types of build, made for different purposes, they'll only add to your ability as a player as you have to develop different play-styles.

So, I'm afraid it's a non-runner as far as I'm concerned. Let alone the work involved in establishing such a thing.

Sorry, but as I said, it's good to see enthusiasm and fresh thoughts!

Cheers

posts.author: gkorjax
posts.content:
I think that basically ANY build in any of the various categories i.e. level 20 builds/30/40 etc are at the top of the game and would do well in most modules. If they are not, it certainly would be brought up in the discussions of that build. It isn't like some one would post a garbage build, and it would be included in the level 40 builds !

One thing that I WOULD point out to you, is that you need to consider your environments carefully. There are MANY level 40 builds that are considered "best" by many, or among the best, that could turn out less than ideal.

Consider for example Webshaman "Nightshade" build, or a variant thereof. If you're aim is to take this through the official campaigns, I'd argue that it ISN"T ideal, because it matures later than those modules go. Not that going pure monk in the OC can't be done, but taking a level of assassin earlier than level 31 (for UMD dump/etc) would reap many benefits. One would probably be better suited looking at the level 20 or level 30 build  sections. Some of the "Best" builds out there mature rather late, and though they are quite powerful, they do sacrifice some playability along the way.

posts.author: unifiedworld
posts.content:
1. I think it would be good if we could try to update links from the previous posts in this thread. It is a stickied thread but most if not all the links on the first page are dead.

2. I wonder if we could make an unofficial "favorite" builds thread, where we let people post their 10 favorite builds of all time. No rating, no comparing, no attempt at being objective - just allowing people to share which builds they like the most. It would be a way for experienced builders/players to pass on their knowledge to new or less experienced players (like me!) 😁

No rating, no comparing, no attempt at being objective - just allowing people to share which builds they like the most. It would be a way for experienced builders/players to pass on their knowledge to new or less experienced players (like me!) 😁
Since we all differ, we could do that for each of the elders. I have my own favorites, but they're not necessarily the same as others'. Still, I'll post a list in the General Discussion forums later.

Right, there would be zero need for any sort of objectivity. That creates all sorts of headaches, so it's better just to let people post their favorite builds. If 10 is too few, then whatever number is appropriate.

If I was more knowledgeable in the game, I would post my own but I really don't know enough and haven't played enough (obviously, most of my experience is limited to the official campaigns) but I would love to hear from others as to which builds are their personal favorite.

posts.author: Pan Draconis
posts.content:
My fav Monk Build : Iron Fist (Orc Version) by Valerfor, for the raw unarmed strenght and the glowing eyes.

My fav Wizard Build : Mestil's half-dead juggernaut by Grizzled Dwarflord. Why ? Becauses it's not a classical wizard gameplay (even if I love playing wizards), one of the tankiest builds ever, easy to play from level 1, and with PM, not so easy to make an efficient wizard with PM.

My fav Pal build : Harper general by Mick Dagger. For the Harper cheese.

My fav buffer/debuffer : Spirit and Steel (also Mick) and every bard build with lasting inspiration and a high level song / curse song.

Other Melee builds I love : Andariel (by Valerfor), the charnel Lord by Grizz.

Melee + buffer / debuffer : Moghedien by Valerfor (the synergy between BG, bard and RDD is insane)
